title: What are the best anime comedies? - Quora

response.answer_text: I’ll categorise the comedy anime I have seen in three (fighting-game-like) tiers: Very good (S tier[1])GoodLess goodHonorable mentionsAll the anime below had, at least for my tastes, a high amount of laughs per episode, among other positive traits. An anime doesn’t have to be a “comedy anime” to be funny and make my tier list. _________________________ Very good (S tier) _________________________ Nichijou  Nichijou is practically the female equivalent of Daily Lives of High School Boys, but more zany and frenetic. The comedy is very physical rather than intellectual. It involves the characters doing things and getting into (or out of) comedic situations. Don’t let the art style fool you into thinking it’s all cutesy and kiddy. It’s not. It has some of the best animation I’ve seen. Strong points include: high amount of laughs per episodemany short skits per episode, while still telling a larger story (somewhat)a show about nothing that is still somehow tremendously entertaininggrounded in everyday lifedoesn’t take itself seriously at all almost no episode is boring; you want to keep watchingsome jokes fall flat or are only understandable by people who understand the Japanese culture, but those are rare and don’t diminish the seriestouching moments that actually say worthwhile things (but not too many, heh)scenes where the characters are shown with strange, deadpan facial expressions  hilarious overreactions (that’s a sausage she’s trying to grab with chop sticks) The pace is intense, but it has moments of calm and some short breaks between some skits, so it goes down well, rather than being overwhelming. I’ll review it one day. But you don’t need that. It’s well worth watching. I recommend it without hesitation. I’ll share some videos of the skits below, so you can get an idea of what it’s like. I’ll share a few, because the style of this show is so off-the-wall that it’s hard to get a good feel for it from just one. One of the skits—three of the main characters out camping:  (continued…)  (continued…)  Another classic skit:  Another recurring skit about a girl who likes a guy, but assaults him with various weapons rather than telling him she likes him:  One of the main characters saying how she saves the best part of her lunch—in this case a frankfurt—for last and the hilarity that ensues:  Another skit featuring three of the main characters—the child Professor (that’s her name) who built a robot called Nano, and a talking cat. Seems kiddy, but these characters are great and add an important contrast to the other characters:  (continued…)  A skit featuring a girl who forgot to do her homework, who asks her friend to borrow her notebook. Her friend gives her the notebook then remembers something:  (continued…)  (continued…)   Daily Lives of High School Boys  Daily Lives of High School Boys (in Japanese: Danshi Koukousei no Nichijou) is practically the male equivalent of Nichijou (which I mentioned above). Strong points include: high amount of laughs per episodemany short skits per episode, while still telling a larger story (somewhat)a show about nothing that is still somehow tremendously entertaininggrounded in everyday lifedoesn’t take itself seriously at all almost no episode is boring; you want to keep watchingsome jokes fall flat or are only understandable by people who understand the Japanese culture, but those are rare and don’t diminish the seriestouching moments that actually say worthwhile things (but not too many, heh)scenes where the characters are shown with strange, deadpan facial expressions The pace is a little slower and less intense than Nichijou. The series is a big parody of the whole anime genre and other things I don’t know enough about to recognise. It also includes a recurring skit called “High School Girls are Funky” that focuses on girls rather than boys. I’ll review it one day. But you don’t need that. It’s well worth watching. I recommend it without hesitation. Trailer:  One of the skits:  Another classic skit (this one is a recurring one throughout the series):  The “High School Girls Are Funky” skit (all of them, actually… just watch a few to get an idea):  _________________________ Good _________________________ The Devil is a Part-Timer!  Get through the first episode, and it’s pretty much great from there on. The basic premise is “take unlikely characters and put them in an unlikely environment and watch what happens.” The result is pretty hilarious. A great thing about this is that it: doesn’t involve high school students (there is one, but the majority of them are older)it isn’t set in a high school and actually includes some workplace scenes and other environments   It looks a bit kiddy due to the art style, but it isn’t. I found the art style quite refreshing and modern, often with vibrant and tasteful use of CGI. I couldn’t find a good trailer, so here’s the episode opening video:  // There are English dub trailers, though I generally stay away from English dubs (though Berserk and DBZ was okay). Other clips won’t do it justice, since this anime is all about context and setup. Working!  Much less zany than both Nichijou and Daily Lives of High School Boys, but still great and enjoyable. It’s about the staff that work at a family restaurant. What a crazy cast they are. Many of them have unrealistic traits, but it results in much hilarity. It doesn’t have the same multiple skits per episode format due to being episodic, though there are many skits within the larger context of that episode. Not quite as many laughs per episode as Daily Lives of High School Boys and Nichijou, but still good. Trailer:   Servant X Service  Much less zany than all of the above, but still great. Based on a manga by the same person who created Working! It’s set in the workplace of a civil servant office. Despite the title, it has nothing to do with BDSM. Not quite as many laughs per episode as Daily Lives of High School Boys and Nichijou, but still good. Trailer:  _________________________ Less good _________________________ None so far.  Anything else I’ve seen doesn’t make the cut. I expect to at least chuckle a few times in the first episode, and have a consistent level of comedy quality throughout the series. If it: starts strong then drops offtakes more than three episodes to get into ithas comedy that is vulgar, lame, or just isn’t funny… it doesn’t make the list. _________________________ Honourable mentions _________________________ One Piece. Less humour per episode and more combat, but the humour can range from good to laugh out loud funny. Silly at times, but it adds a lightness to the series that makes it enjoyable. The pacing can be pretty bad, because they add filler to the anime so that it keeps up with the manga. We need a One Piece: Kai (filler cut out).Footnotes[1] In some games, the rank above A is S. I've been following Anime for more than a decade now and I don't remember much in detail about the hundreds of anime I've watched over the years, so I'll just make a list of them with what I remember. Baka to test to shoukanjuu was the series that made me laugh the most, it was mostly slapstick kind of comedy but it worked very effectively. Theere is highschool battle element to it which makes things interesting. It has 2 seasons and both are very enjoyable. Saiki kusuo is a brilliant series with unique style of comedy but not uncommon for japanese programs. It employ fast pace of talking and episodic format with character development taking lower precedence than comedy but not ignored completely. It's about Saiki a high school boy with overpowered psychic abilities that is controlled by 2 tiny hairclips on his head. Even though he is a logical and aloof type of person, all kinds of people are attracted towards him because of his genuine nature and the Saiki group is formed. Guaranteed to make anyone laugh. The art is minimal but not bad. Grand blue - is one of the recent ones. It's about a bunch of scooba diving enthusiasts belonging to a scooba diving club. Two new recruits, college students join the bunch, discover drinking, scooba diving and fooling around while trying to entertain us with College Life and slapstick comedy. Next to baka to test this series made me laugh the most. Art is also excellent and fan service is also a part of its charm. School rumble - is relatively old but memorable comedy series. It really does things in a simple innocent way. The characters are also simple and innocent. The main characters are a highschool delinquent type guy and a simple minded girl he has a crush on. The story between the two takes precedence and worth a try for its heartwarming effort. Yahari Ore no Seishun Love Comedy wa Machigatteiru - this is the highest recommended by me of the list because I enjoy intelligent comedy more than slapstick even though slapstick gets more laughs. This series is like life of debate between the high school boy who is pessimistic and highly pragmatic and a his classmate who is a super sophisticated and straight A’s girl. How the boy thinks, how the girls thinks and clash between them , the debates and reconciliation form the crux of the story. The charactor development takes precedence here and the developments in the story are just too good to leave it without binge watching. Prison school - prison school comes into those category of anime that are extremely refined, and seemed to know how to deliver something precisely though at the expense of being formulaic. It belongs to the likes of baka toh test and grand blue where the laugh delivery is instant and effective. Weighing in heavily on the slapstick delivery, it tells the struggles and tribulations of a bunch of high school boys who are a minority in a previously all girls school with a unique system that enforces prison time as punishments and disciplinary action by the student president and prefect body. The boys are viewed as vile creatures by the residents and some normal youthful adventures from the boys ends up getting them thrown in the prison. Plenty of potential for comedy with the said setting and very effectively used. There are a set of series like Kaichou wa maid-sama, Seitokai yakuindomo, Kaguya-sama: Love Is War that belong to a set of comedies that are focused on seto kai or the school prefect leader setup. Though each of them have very different delivery systems. Kaichou wa maid-sama is the oldest and can be said to be the one that really started the wave of seto kai based comedies so I would recommend that. It's about a school prefect leader who is also works as a maid in a cafe. Her secret revealed accidentally to a guy and story continues. Kaguya sama is the most different and recent of these. Its a story of awkwardness between two people in love, the perfect body president and the vice president. They are not ready to admit to the other their love before the other concedes and admits it. They try their hardest to feign professionalism and indifference and come up with plots to confirm the feeling of the other and Love becomes a war, where one who admits first is the loser. Though there are a plenty of others I enjoyed and can be recommended these remain one of my favorites. And it hope to see more from. I have deliberately not included those that start at comedy and go of to more serious hardcore tracks though they were very enjoyable.
